STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 16, 2022
Donata Kidd
Muskegon County DHHS
2700 Baker
Muskegon Heights, MI 49444
RE: License #: CP610201318
Muskegon County DHHS
2700 Baker
Muskegon Heights, MI 49444
Dear Ms. Kidd:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on August 11,
2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION

Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902

Muskegon Heights, MI 49444

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least
once every 90 calendar days.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have the Updated Service Plan
completed timely.
File one: 1/18/2022 USP not submitted timely (1/20/2022), 4/18/2022 USP not
submitted timely (4/19/2022).
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06H Quality visits
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have been found
to produce positive outcomes for children in foster care. A quality
visit is defined as one in which the caseworker:
 Can meet with each child individually, without the presence of
other individuals, to give the child an opportunity to ask
questions as well as discuss the current placement.
 Views the child's bedroom and sleeping arrangements.
 Verifies safe sleep environments and practices for infants
under 12 months.
 Assesses each child’s educational, medical, dental, mental
health and other needs and takes appropriate action or offers
services in response to the identified needs of each child.
4

 Shows interest in the child to build and establish rapport.
 Shares and explains the case plan, including the plan for
parenting time, visits with siblings and other relatives, and the
child's permanency plan, in a developmentally appropriate
way while allowing the child to ask questions and express
viewpoints.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation of a quality visit.
File one: 12/9/2021, 1/4/2022, & 2/3/2022 home visits do not document a quality visit
was conducted.
File two: 3/8/2022 & 4/13/2022 home visits do not document a quality visit was
conducted.
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the case
service plan within 14 days as required.
FOM 722-08C Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth aged 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures on
the parent agency treatment plan (PATP).
File one: there are no PATP's uploaded for 9/23/2021, 2/22/2022, or 5/23/2022.
12/22/2021 PATP contains father’s signature, but foster parent signature is not
uploaded.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/2/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/4/2021, cited under MISEP 6.19
10/22/2020 INTERIM, CAP approved 12/2/2020
FOM 722-06H Contact with parent or guardian when child is placed out-of-
home
First Month after Initial Out-of-Home Placement
5

The primary foster care caseworker must have at least two face-
to-face contacts with the legal parent or guardian, with at least
one contact occurring at the parent or guardian's home or living
environment, during the first month following initial out-of-home
placement.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation face-to-face
contact occurred with parents in their home within the 1st month of out of home
placement. There is no documentation attempts were made to schedule.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Four of eight foster care files reviewed did not have FTM’s completed as required.
File one: There is no corresponding FTM for 5/23/2022 USP.
File two: There is no corresponding FTM for 6/7/2022 USP. 6/8/2022 FTM is not able
to be used.
File three: There is no corresponding FTM for 10/20/2021 USP.
File four: There is no corresponding FTM for 10/25/2021 USP.
FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Five of eight foster care files reviewed contained FTM’s without the DHS 1105 or the
DHS 1105 was not uploaded within seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/2/2021 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/4/2021, cited under MISEP 6.19
10/22/2020 INTERIM, CAP approved 12/2/2020
6

FOM 801-03 Medical passports
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
 All medical and mental health professionals to whom the child
is newly referred to and accepted for treatment and/or
services prior to or at the first scheduled appointment while
the foster care case is open, regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
 Older youth/young adults:
Upon initial independent living placement (youth age 16
and over).
Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults age
18 and older).
Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult:
Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary foster care.
Upon exiting voluntary foster care.
One of eight open foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and
required signatures.
File one: There are no medical passports completed since 2/1/2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Make sure to code supervision social work contacts correctly. A few were
entered as case contact instead of supervision.
 PATP signatures must include the date.
7

 Reminder to generate and save reports.
 Ensure all social work contacts are thorough and completed before approving
report.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
The facility did not request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
renewal inspection completed on 9/2/2021 with a corrective action plan approved on
10/4/2021. During the review the agency had ten violations. Two citations were
noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period under review
the agency did not identify any barriers that impacted overall compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment reported the agency has made significant effort
to meet requirements during this review period. The Chief Administrator stated the
previous year CAP was effective due to processes being put in place that the
agency feels has reduced the number of citations. The Chief Administrator
assessment reported ongoing challenges related to disrupted and unplanned
removal of children from foster homes. The Chief Administrator indicated additional
oversight, including internal auditing, development of CAP driven inter-office policies
and procedures, and implementation of checklists have had a positive impact on
overall compliance. The Chief Administrator expressed confidence that several
areas will continue improve over the next review period.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with four staff via telephone. Staff acknowledged there
were some challenges related to staffing but, overall, felt as though the agency has
addressed as well as they can. Staff reported it would be helpful if good ideas within
one unit was implemented to other units as well. Staff reported feeling supported by
supervisors and co-workers and reported no areas of need.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
8

receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
____________8/11/2022__________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 15, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
